nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
General site characteristics
nodes.body: DringakGrib ’gag is located in the mouth of a valley hat overlooks the bes sbug mtsho basin, which is to the south. The site is also in the shadow of a red mountain called Marpo DamchokDmar po dam phyog. This locale is part of a region traditionally known as dang chung stod ma. The six funerary structures of DringakGrib ’gagare situated on both benches that flank a stream. The obdurate terrain is level, sandy and gravelly. The presence of a house on each side of the stream, as well as Manima ṇi walls and tsa tsa khangtshwa tshwa khang indicate that the site has been heavily disturbed. The fragmentary structures mostly consist of double-course enclosures with walls hat are flush with the surface or which slightly project above it. Due to their disintegration, the precise shape of the enclosures is no longer clear. Several types of uncut, variable-length blocky rocks and a few slabs (20 cm o 50 cm long) went into the construction of the enclosures.

nodes.title: East bench
nodes.body:
The east bench is slightly lower in elevation than the west bench.

  1. Funerary structure FS5 (2.5 m x 2.2 m) is completely sheathed in embedded stones and appears to represent an alternative type of funerary structure (17.102΄ / 33.454΄).
  2. Funerary structure FS6 (5.8 m across) has the remains of double-course perimeter walls around 75 cm thick (17.097΄ / 33.462΄).

nodes.title: lCags rde’u
nodes.body: On the opposite or northeast side of the Marpo DamchokDmar po dam phyog mountain, there are reported to be the vestiges of other funerary superstructures. This site is called ChakdeuLcags rde’u (Iron Hill). It is said hat in 2001, a youth discovered human skeletal remains washed out of a gully at ChakdeuLcags rde’u.
